He had also done work on the bliss point, showing how a product’s allure is contextual, shaped partly by the other foods a person is eating, and that it changes as people age.
Toppels, a cracker with cheese topping; Stuffers, a shell with a variety of fillings; Rumbles, a bite-size granola snack — they all came and went in a blink, and the company took a $52 million hit.
The largest single block of customers, the baby boomers, had begun hitting middle age.
According to the research, this suggested that their liking for salty snacks — both in the concentration of salt and how much they ate — would be tapering off.
Around that time, the marketing team was joined by Dwight Riskey, an expert on cravings who had been a fellow at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, where he was part of a team of scientists that found that people could beat their salt habits simply by refraining from salty foods long enough for their taste buds to return to a normal level of sensitivity.
This seemed to help explain why Frito-Lay was having so much trouble selling new snacks.
The company had introduced a series of high-profile products that failed miserably.
Not much had changed by 1986, except Frito-Lay found itself on a rare cold streak.
Along with the rest of the snack-food industry, Frito-Lay anticipated lower sales because of an aging population, and marketing plans were adjusted to focus even more intently on younger consumers.

I tracked Lin down in Irvine, Calif., where we spent several days going through the internal company memos, strategy papers and handwritten notes he had kept.
The documents were evidence of the concern that Lin had for consumers and of the company’s intent on using science not to address the health concerns but to thwart them.
By chance, I ran across a letter that Lin sent to Karppanen three weeks after that dinner, buried in some files to which I had gained access.
While at Frito-Lay, Lin and other company scientists spoke openly about the country’s excessive consumption of sodium and the fact that, as Lin said to me on more than one occasion, “people get addicted to salt.”
Attached to the letter was a memo written when Lin was at Frito-Lay, which detailed some of the company’s efforts in defending salt.

He had also done work on the bliss point, showing how a product’s allure is contextual, shaped partly by the other foods a person is eating, and that it changes as people age.
Toppels, a cracker with cheese topping; Stuffers, a shell with a variety of fillings; Rumbles, a bite-size granola snack — they all came and went in a blink, and the company took a $52 million hit.
The largest single block of customers, the baby boomers, had begun hitting middle age.
According to the research, this suggested that their liking for salty snacks — both in the concentration of salt and how much they ate — would be tapering off.
Around that time, the marketing team was joined by Dwight Riskey, an expert on cravings who had been a fellow at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, where he was part of a team of scientists that found that people could beat their salt habits simply by refraining from salty foods long enough for their taste buds to return to a normal level of sensitivity.
This seemed to help explain why Frito-Lay was having so much trouble selling new snacks.
The company had introduced a series of high-profile products that failed miserably.
Not much had changed by 1986, except Frito-Lay found itself on a rare cold streak.
Along with the rest of the snack-food industry, Frito-Lay anticipated lower sales because of an aging population, and marketing plans were adjusted to focus even more intently on younger consumers.

But what they weren’t measuring, Riskey realized, is how those snacking habits of the boomers compared to themselves when they were in their 20s.
Poring over data one day in his home office, trying to understand just who was consuming all the snack food, Riskey realized that he and his colleagues had been misreading things all along.
They had been measuring the snacking habits of different age groups and were seeing what they expected to see, that older consumers ate less than those in their 20s.
“In fact, as those people aged, their consumption of all those segments — the cookies, the crackers, the candy, the chips — was going up,” Riskey said.
When he called up a new set of sales data and performed what’s called a cohort study, following a single group over time, a far more encouraging picture — for Frito-Lay, anyway — emerged.
Except that snack sales didn’t decline as everyone had projected, Frito-Lay’s doomed product launches notwithstanding.
The baby boomers were not eating fewer salty snacks as they aged.
In fact, everyone in the country, on average, was eating more salty snacks than they used to.
“They were not only eating what they ate when they were younger, they were eating more of it.”
The rate of consumption was edging up about one-third of a pound every year, with the average intake of snacks like chips and cheese crackers pushing past 12 pounds a year.
